bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to [Jefferson Randolph Kean], August 22, 1896

div1.p: Reed apologizes for not sending the vaccine earlier and jokes about his devotion to the mango. Reed also is excited about the possibility of [Kean] working in his laboratory. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to [Jefferson Randolph Kean], August 22, 1896
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
August 22. '96
My dear Doctor:
div1.p:
Please
do not consider me an
ingrate. Many thanks for
your very kind letter
of August 10th, which
I have left unanswered
simply because I was
so busy with the Surg=
eon General's work, that
I could call no time
my own. How I long
once more for that dream-
life at Key-West! I was
not at all uneasy about
my valuable notes, for I
knew that they were in
your hands thence per-
fectly safe. I shall need
them next week, when I
come to put my article
in some kind of shape.
I owe you many apologies
for my neglect to send the
vaccine. It goes by to-day's
mail. An oesc should
be all that you need for
each vaccination. I shudder
to think that dear little
innocent Martha should
be compelled to undergo,
once more, an abrasion
of her cuticle! I have not
ceased to blame myself for
the pain that I inflicted
upon her, at her cruel fa-
ther's suggestion.

Just prior to her departure
from the city Mrs. Reed re=
ceived your letter. I sup=
posed that she has an=
swered it before this, and
that she has doubtless made
some very wild statements
about my integrity as a
witness. I, for one, was
shocked, my dear Doctor, over
your lack of belief in
my devotion to the Mango!
The one thing that comforts me
is my knowledge that Mrs. Kean
has never, for an instant,
doubted this devotion on
my part. I not only brought
them home, scorning all other
fruit, by the way side, but shared
them with others, very unwilling=
ly, after my arrival. Call me
a Silverite, if you will, but
never an anti-mangoish!
The possibility of having you
in my laboratory, this fall makes,
me very happy. If you will come,
you shall have the best window,
best microscope and best attention.
I can't offer anything more than a
hearty welcome and an occasional
“cock-tail”. Make my warmest regards
to Mrs. Kean and my most profound obeisance
to Miss Martha.
